description.p: The tshirt shows "open standards". "open" is formed as a telephone cable, connecting two tiny little robots. The back side is empty.
The tshirt shows some doves as a symbol for data being freed from a floppy disc. The back side is empty.
The tshirt shows "I love Free Software" on the front and some small hearts and "fsfe.org" on the back.

info.name: Free Software Free Society and GNU, blue

description.p: The T-shirt shows the "Free Software Free Society" slogan on the front with www.fsfe.org and the GNU head on the back, made with tiny FSFE logos.

description.p: The T-shirt shows the "Free Software Free Society" slogan on the front with www.fsfe.org and the GNU head on the back, made with tiny FSFE logos.
The T-shirt shows the Fellowship logo and the German text "Mach Dich Frei!" on the front and the URL of the Fellowship page (fsfe.org) with included FSFE logo on the back.
The T-shirt shows the Fellowship logo and the text "Hacking for Freedom" on the front and the URL of the Fellowship page (www.fsfe.org) on the back.

The Fellowship keyring also contains a shopping cart chip.
This analog printer is interoperable and works on every platforms. Highly hackable, it uses open standards.

info.name: Analog printer, business-style pen, dark blue

description.p: This analog printer is interoperable and works on every platforms. Highly hackable, it uses open standards and comes with a shiny box.
People who spend their nights hacking for freedom usually drink a lot of coffee.

Many Fellows use this lanyard keychain to carry their Fellowship smart card around their neck.
